title: David Cameron: Boris Johnson ‘didn’t believe’ in Brexit
text:
David Cameron ripped into the political motives of Johnson and Michael Gove | Facundo Arrizabalaga/EPA-EFE David Cameron: Boris Johnson ‘didn’t believe’ in Brexit Former PM rips into successor and accuses Gove of disloyalty.

David Cameron has accused Boris Johnson of not believing in Brexit but backing it anyway during the referendum campaign on Britain's EU membership to advance his political career.

In an extract from his forthcoming memoir, published in the Sunday Times, the former British prime minister ripped into the political motives of Johnson and Michael Gove, another leading Brexit campaigner who is now a Cabinet minister.

Writing of the current PM, who has pledged to take the U.K. out of the EU by October 31, Cameron said: “The conclusion I am left with is that he risked an outcome he didn’t believe in because it would help his political career.”

He added that Johnson "was certain the Brexit side would lose. So backing it brought little risk of breaking up the government he wanted to lead one day. It would be a risk-free bet on himself."

Cameron said that one of the "greatest miscalculations I made was that I thought moderate Eurosceptics would see, like me, that staying in and fighting, with new reforms agreed, with all the opt-outs secured, with all the advantages over trade and co-operation, was the right course."

But Cameron is most critical of Gove. He accuses Gove of stabbing him of stabbing him in the back as soon as Cameron had struck a deal in Brussels meant to allay domestic concerns about the U.K.'s EU membership, especially on immigration.

“As for Michael, one quality shone through: disloyalty. Disloyalty to me and, later, disloyalty to Boris,” Cameron wrote.

“By the end, Boris and Michael seemed to me to be different people. Boris had backed something he didn’t believe in. Michael had backed something he did perhaps believe in, but in the process had broken with his friends ... while taking up positions that were completely against his political identity," the former prime minister wrote.

"Both then behaved appallingly, attacking their own government, turning a blind eye to their side’s unpleasant actions and becoming ambassadors for the expert-trashing, truth-twisting age of populism.”

Cameron also called the Brexit campaign "a cauldron of toxicity, including figures such as Nigel Farage, Dominic Cummings and the businessman Arron Banks."

Other government ministers also got scathing reviews for their part in the Brexit campaign. Of Priti Patel, the current home secretary and a former employment minister, Cameron said: "She used every announcement, interview and speech to hammer the government on immigration, even though she was part of that government. I was stuck, though, unable to fire her, because that would make her a Brexit martyr.”

He also accused Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn of failing to commit to the Remain campaign, saying he “delivered a handful of desultory speeches about remain and then went on holiday. Perhaps Corbyn wanted remain to lose.”
description: Former PM rips into successor and accuses Gove of disloyalty.
